clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Value of Left Atrial Appendage Flow for Prediction of Successful Catheter Ablation for Persistent Atrial Fibrillation
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Value of Left Atrial Appendage Flow for Prediction of Successful Catheter Ablation for Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study was to determine whether left atrial appendage flow velocity, as determined using trans esophageal echocardiography (TEE), predicts the outcome after catheter ablation of persistent Atrial fibrillation( pAF).

detailed_description.textblock: 40 PAF patients underwent 3D mapping and ablation. A stepwise approach including circumferential pulmonary vein (PV) isolation, continuous complex-fractionated electrogram (CFE) ablation and linear ablation was performed by the same operator. The procedural end point was termination of persistent AF by catheter ablation, either by conversion directly to sinus rhythm or to atrial tachycardia. Left atrial appendage (LAA) peak flow velocities were measured with transesophageal echography and averaged within each RR interval of 10 consecutive cardiac cycles.

primary_outcome.measure: termination of persistent AF by catheter ablation

secondary_outcome.measure: Recurrences of AF were therefore determined from holter monitoring at 3 and 6 months or 12 leads ECG in care of symptomatic palpitation with clinical interview.

arm_group.arm_group_label: patients with persistent atrial fibrillation ablation

intervention.description: All patients were evaluated by a complete transesophageal echocardiography with multiplane probes with a 7-MHz transducer before catheter ablation .LA appendage flow was obtained by placing the pulsed Doppler sample volume at the orifice of the LA appendage, after which peak flow velocities were measured and averaged within each RR interval of 10 consecutive cardiac cycles
intervention.arm_group_label: patients with persistent atrial fibrillation ablation

study_pop.textblock: 40 consecutive patients who underwent first-time radiofrequency catheter ablation for pAF. pAF was defined as continuous AF lasting longer than 1 month, resistant to either electrical or pharmacological cardioversion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- First-time radiofrequency catheter ablation for pAF. pAF was defined as continuous AF lasting longer than 1 month, resistant to either electrical or pharmacological cardioversion.
- Informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe valvular disease requiring surgery
- Valvular prosthesis
- Known severe coronary artery disease
- Atrial and/or ventricular thrombosis
- New York Heart Association functional class III to IV
- Cerebrovascular disease
- Pulmonary embolism
- Latent or manifest hyperthyroidism
